All the kids and the hubby thoroughly enjoyed them! They will be made on repeat!\r\n\r\nAfter I put the bars in the fridge to set/chill, I wasn't able to bake them until 3 or 4 hours later. From what I can tell, the extra refrigeration didn't hurt them at all.\r\n\r\nTo add a bit of airiness, I used 90 g of rolled oats and 30 g of Ricies (which is about 1 cup of Ricies) instead of only oats. I didn't toast them though as I figured they would probably burn.\r\n\r\nI baked them for a total of 17 minutes - checking them at 15 minutes as I read in a previous comment that they are prone to burning if your oven runs hot as I suspect mine does. "caption": "Nagi"}, "description": "I believe you can make great food with everyday ingredients even if you\u2019re short on time and cost conscious. You just need to cook clever and get creative!", "sameAs": ["http://www.recipetineats.com/about-me/"], "url": "https://www.recipetineats.com/author/nagi-maehashigmail-com/"}, {"@type": "Recipe", "name": "Hot Ham and Cheese Sliders", "author": {"@id": "https://www.recipetineats.com/#/schema/person/1684e6a75e9f91ae2e33ca2de95b47e2"}, "description": "Recipe video above. You can&#39;t imagine how good a ham sandwich can be until you&#39;ve tried Hot Ham and Cheese Sliders! Rolls stuffed with ham and cheese smothered in a tangy mustard onion butter sauce baked until the cheese is melty, this American game-day favourite is excellent big-batch party food that is leftover Christmas ham-worthy. The mustard and onion really works in this, lending savouriness and tang that sets this apart from  the usual boring lunchbox ham sandwiches! And there&#39;s probably less butter per roll (1 3/4 tsp each) than if you spread it on like usual. Pork Adobo is the pride of the Philippines - one bite and you&#39;ll be hooked! Pork braised until meltingly tender in an intense soy-garlic sauce that reduces down to a glaze, served over steaming rice, this is food so good yet so simple to make, you&#39;ll be shaking your head in disbelief.Our adobo sauce has a well rounded flavour, intensely savoury but not overly salty or too sour (some restaurants make it really sour), and not too sweet. The sauce is meant to be thin so a little goes a long way on your rice.Slow cooker not recommended, sorry, see Note 6.", "datePublished": "2025-08-13T16:03:43+00:00", "image": ["https://www.recipetineats.com/tachyon/2025/08/Pork-Adobo-over-rice.jpg", "https://www.recipetineats.com/tachyon/2025/08/Pork-Adobo-over-rice.jpg?resize=500%2C500", "https://www.recipetineats.com/tachyon/2025/08/Pork-Adobo-over-rice.jpg?resize=500%2C375", "https://www.recipetineats.com/tachyon/2025/08/Pork-Adobo-over-rice.jpg?resize=480%2C270"], "recipeYield": ["4", "4 - 5 people"], "prepTime": "PT10M", "cookTime": "PT120M", "recipeIngredient": ["1 kg/ 2 lb  pork shoulder  ((the parts ribboned with fat not lean parts), skinless, cut into 6cm/2.5&quot; cubes - or belly (Note 1))", "2 tbsp vegetable oil (, or any other neutral flavoured oil)", "1  large onion (, cut in half then 0.8\" / 1/3\" wedges)", "8 cloves garlic (, finely sliced)", "3 cups water", "1/2 cup light soy sauce (, sub regular/all-purpose soy (Note 2))", "1 1/2 tsp dark soy sauce ((Note 2))", "1/4 cup rice vinegar ((sub regular white vinegar))", "3 tbsp (tightly packed) brown sugar", "1 1/2 tsp black peppercorns (, can omit (Note 3))", "5  bay leaves (, preferably fresh, dried ok too)", "6  pineapple rings (, each cut into 8 pieces, from canned pineapple in juice not syrup, or 2 cups fresh pineapple pieces)", "2 tsp vegetable oil (, or any other neutral flavoured oil)", "1  green onion (, finely sliced)", "2 batches jasmine rice"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToSection", "name": "ABBREVIATED:", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Brown pork, remove, saut\u00e9 onion and garlic, add everything else. This is a classical French-style recipe for homemade beef stock. It&#39;s vastly superior to any store-bought stock, and is one of the main things that distinguishes home and restaurant cooking.It takes time to make, but if you truly want the best, it&#39;s worth it!Makes: 1.25 - 1.5 L / quarts stock (5 - 6 cups), ready use store-bought strength, UNSALTED. So worth the effort!!!", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Debra Caroline McCallum"}, "datePublished": "2025-09-03"}, {"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "reviewBody": "You said you find it harder to measure the stock when in jelly form. I use a small set of scales so that whatever my need *ml or oz or grams), I just weigh out everything in grams (28gram to the oz, or 1 gram to one ml). Fast, simple, accurate. Great recipe though thank you. Sound advice for all even though I go off piste and do things my way (but then again I always do....!). I use aged beef meat bones (quite meaty) and salvage the meat after making the stock and use it in a madras curry as you don't notice the flavour has been sucked out of the meat. I also salvage the tallow fat from the bones after roasting for any number of skillet uses or bacon frying. Too many cured salmon recipes are way too salty ot way too sweet! But once you know the right propotions, it&#39;s ridiculously simple to make and far cheaper than buying equivalent shop-bought versions.Gently flavoured with spices and a little vodka or gin, this a show-stopping, sophisticated-looking modern classic. Wonderful elegant canape or individually plated starter (fine dining favourite!), as part of an antipasto platter or cheeseboard, or just generally having in the fridge to nibble or use in sandwiches!1kg / 2 lb salmon will easily serve 16 people as a starter (slices are cut thinly)Start this recipe at least 2 days before serving, preferably 3 days.", "datePublished": "2021-03-31T15:00:00+00:00", "image": ["https://www.recipetineats.com/tachyon/2021/03/Beetroot-Cured-Salmon_0-1-copy.jpg", "https://www.recipetineats.com/tachyon/2021/03/Beetroot-Cured-Salmon_0-1-copy.jpg?resize=500%2C500", "https://www.recipetineats.com/tachyon/2021/03/Beetroot-Cured-Salmon_0-1-copy.jpg?resize=500%2C375", "https://www.recipetineats.com/tachyon/2021/03/Beetroot-Cured-Salmon_0-1-copy.jpg?resize=480%2C270"], "recipeYield": ["12", "12 - 16 people"], "prepTime": "PT10M", "recipeIngredient": ["1kg/ 2 lb  single piece of fresh salmon", "400g/ 14 oz  beetroot/beet ((raw), peeled and diced in 1cm / 0.5&quot; They look so innocent when placed before you - then they explode with colourful fillings when you smash into them! Show aside, the flavour and texture combination here is just incredible.Shockingly easy to make - just poke a hole in the base of small pavs (so much easier to make than a single large one!), and fill with whatever you want. Think, passionfruit pulp, mango puree, chopped fruit, chocolate sauce, caramel sauce! This rustic Italian classic is fabulously quick to make thanks to thin slices of veal that cook in 2 1/2 minutes flat. Traditionally made with veal, Saltimbocca is also excellent with chicken or beef. The trick to a great Saltimbocca sauce is to slowly melt in cubes of cold butter by swirling the pan off the heat. This thickens the sauce and makes it luxuriously silky. It&#39;s a stunner! Long time cook &amp; baker here! Pork tenderloin and pork loin are NOT the same thing. Pork tenderoins are smaller, averaging 1 lb each with 2 in a vaccuum pack. Pork loins are larger in diameter and are not as tender. Think of chicken breast and chicken tenders. The tenders/tenderloin is smaller and protected around by the other cut, which is larger and can be tougher. Certainly the flavors are very similar and some people would. say they are the same. The rule of thumb is first time you try a new recipe, make it the way it is written and second time you make it, do your little adaptations if needed.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Michelle K Drozdibob"}, "datePublished": "2023-05-22"}, {"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "reviewBody": "Wanted a different way to make Pork Tenderloin. The smooth definitely needed chilled, but at the end of the day, neither one of them baked up right.  I even used brand new oven temp gauges to make sure my ovens were heating up to temp.  I do love me a bit of a crisper, but not HARD, cookie. Cheese Souffl\u00e9 is a traditional French dish that combines simple pantry staples into something truly special. It rises beautifully in the oven, with a golden top and soft, airy centre. Don\u2019t be intimidated by the name, it\u2019s easier than you think to make it at home.\u00a0I promise! I still remember my restaurant days, total chaos every time a souffl\u00e9 came out of the oven. Someone would shout \u201cSouffl\u00e9!!\u201d and hope the wait staff appeared instantly, because one thing\u2019s for sure: Souffl\u00e9 doesn\u2019t wait.", "datePublished": "2025-10-24T16:00:00+00:00", "image": ["https://www.recipetineats.com/tachyon/2025/10/Cheese-souffle_6.jpg", "https://www.recipetineats.com/tachyon/2025/10/Cheese-souffle_6.jpg?resize=500%2C500", "https://www.recipetineats.com/tachyon/2025/10/Cheese-souffle_6.jpg?resize=500%2C375", "https://www.recipetineats.com/tachyon/2025/10/Cheese-souffle_6.jpg?resize=480%2C270"], "recipeYield": ["4", "4 people"], "prepTime": "PT15M", "cookTime": "PT30M", "totalTime": "PT45M", "recipeIngredient": ["2 cups full fat milk (, but works with lite milk too)", "75 g (5 tbsp)  unsalted butter", "1/2 cup plain flour (all-purpose)", "1/2 tsp cooking salt / kosher salt ((halve for table salt, + 50% for flakes))", "2 pinches ground white pepper ((substitute black pepper))", "150 g (1 1/2 cups)  Gruy\u00e8re cheese (, shredded using a standard box grater (tightly packed if using cups) (Note 2 for other cheeses))", "3  egg yolks (from large eggs (55g/2oz each in shell), at room temperature (Note 1))", "4  egg whites (from large eggs, at room temperature (total egg whites ~ 120g/4.2oz, Note1))", "1/2 tsp cream of tartar (, sifted if lumpy (Note 3))", "15 g (1 tbsp)  unsalted butter (, melted (to grease the ramekins))"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToSection", "name": "ABBREVIATED RECIPE", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Melt butter, cook flour 2 minutes, whisk in warm milk in 3 batches. Add salt and pepper, turn off heat, whisk in yolks one at a time, then melt through gruyere over low heat. Beat egg whites and cream of tartar to firm peaks, starting on medium for 2 minutes, then increasing to high. Whisk 1/4 of the whites into Mornay Sauce, then fold through remainder in 3 batches. Fill butter brushed ramekins to 1cm/0.4\u201d from rim, clean inside of rim. Bake at 200\u00b0C/400\u00b0F (180\u00b0C fan) for 20 minutes. No peeking! Serve immediately.", "name": "Melt butter, cook flour 2 minutes, whisk in warm milk in 3 batches. Set aside.", "url": "https://www.recipetineats.com/cheese-souffle-souffle-au-fromage/#wprm-recipe-187853-step-2-0"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Make the roux - While the milk is heating, let\u2019s start our roux. In a large saucepan, melt the butter over medium heat. Once melted, add the flour. Whisk it gently, it will be thick and pasty at first like a wet sand. Cook, whisking constantly, for about 2 minutes. It will thin up and become smooth and glossy. Make sure to use the whisk to get into the corners of the pot and don\u2019t let it brown. Reduce heat if you think it\u2019s too high.", "name": "Make the roux - While the milk is heating, let\u2019s start our roux. In a large saucepan, melt the butter over medium heat. Once melted, add the flour. Whisk it gently, it will be thick and pasty at first like a wet sand. Cook, whisking constantly, for about 2 minutes. It will thin up and become smooth and glossy. Make sure to use the whisk to get into the corners of the pot and don\u2019t let it brown. Reduce heat if you think it\u2019s too high.", "url": "https://www.recipetineats.com/cheese-souffle-souffle-au-fromage/#wprm-recipe-187853-step-2-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Make B\u00e9chamel - Add a third of the hot milk to the roux while whisking vigorously, it will thicken very quickly. Add half of the leftover milk, whisk until smooth and then pour the rest of it along with the salt and pepper. Keep whisking for 30 seconds to a minute until thickened and smooth, lumps will go away.  It will be thick enough so you can draw a path with a spatula in the middle, it should hold its shape for a moment before slowly sinking back.", "name": "Make B\u00e9chamel - Add a third of the hot milk to the roux while whisking vigorously, it will thicken very quickly. Add half of the leftover milk, whisk until smooth and then pour the rest of it along with the salt and pepper. Keep whisking for 30 seconds to a minute until thickened and smooth, lumps will go away. Then, turn the heat back on to medium and whisk in the grated Gruy\u00e8re until melted through. Scrape down the sides and cover with a lid. Using a hand mixer or a stand mixer fitted with a whisk attachment, beat the egg whites on medium speed for 2 minutes then high speed for 30 seconds until you get firm peaks. Starting slowly helps the protein structure to develop properly. Rush it and you risk unstable, foamy whites that collapse when folded in.", "name": "Beat the egg whites, gently at first\u00a0-\u00a0Add egg whites and the cream of tartar in a large bowl. Then gently fold a third of the remaining egg whites in using a rubber spatula until mostly incorporated. Use slow, sweeping motions from the bottom of the pot, you want to keep as much air in as possible. (See video at 2.15 minutes) Rough folding = flat souffl\u00e9. Few lumps are ok. Repeat twice more with the rest of the egg whites.", "name": "Fold gently -\u00a0Give the Mornay a quick whisk to make it smooth again then add in a quarter of the egg whites and whisk it in to loosen it. Use slow, sweeping motions from the bottom of the pot, you want to keep as much air in as possible. (See video at 2.15 minutes) Rough folding = flat souffl\u00e9. Few lumps are ok. Smooth the tops with the back of a teaspoon dipped in water, no need to be 100% meticulous here, just get rid of big bumps. Run your thumb around the inside rim of each ramekin to clean it, this gives the souffl\u00e9 a clean edge to rise against.", "name": "Fill the ramekins -\u00a0Pour the mixture evenly into the ramekins using a ladle or a large serving spoon, filling to about 1cm / 0.4&quot; below the rim. Farro is so much more interesting than pasta or rice! This salad has stellar flavour and texture: nutty farro, juicy burst cherry tomatoes, spinach bits and smeary goats cheese or feta, doused in an addictive hot garlic olive oil dressing with pops of coriander and cumin. You&#39;ll love how we cook the farro - it&#39;s delicious even more you add everything else. Serves 4 as a meal, 8 as a side. Excellent shelf life and brilliant for taking to gatherings - see notes.", "datePublished": "2023-09-04T16:00:00+00:00", "image": ["https://www.recipetineats.com/tachyon/2023/09/Farro-salad_5.jpg", "https://www.recipetineats.com/tachyon/2023/09/Farro-salad_5.jpg?resize=500%2C500", "https://www.recipetineats.com/tachyon/2023/09/Farro-salad_5.jpg?resize=500%2C375", "https://www.recipetineats.com/tachyon/2023/09/Farro-salad_5.jpg?resize=480%2C270"], "recipeYield": ["4", "4 - 8"], "prepTime": "PT10M", "cookTime": "PT45M", "recipeIngredient": ["1 cup farro (, dried, whole (Note 1))", "1 cup apple cider vinegar ((Note 2))", "2 cups water", "1 tsp cooking/kosher salt", "400g/ 14oz (4 cups)  grape tomatoes ((or cherry tomatoes))", "1 tbsp olive oil", "1/4 tsp each salt and pepper", "1  eschallot (, halved then finely sliced (sub 1/4 red onion) (Note 3))", "2 tightly packed cups  baby spinach (, roughly chopped (sub arugula/baby rocket))", "80g/ 3oz  goats cheese (or 120g/4 oz Danish feta (Note 4))", "2 tbsp extra virgin olive oil", "1 1/2 tbsp garlic (, finely minced (~4 cloves))", "2 tsp coriander seeds", "1 1/2 tsp cumin seeds"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat oven to 200\u00b0C/400\u00b0F (180\u00b0C fan).", "name": "Preheat oven to 200\u00b0C/400\u00b0F (180\u00b0C fan).", "url": "https://www.recipetineats.com/farro-salad-with-sizzled-dressing/#wprm-recipe-118808-step-0-0"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Roast tomatoes and toast farro - Toss tomatoes on a tray with the olive oil, salt and pepper. Spread farro on a separate tray. Put both in the oven, farro on the top shelf, tomatoes underneath. Bake for 8 minutes, shaking the trays halfway. The farro should be browned with a nutty flavour, the tomatoes should be a bit wrinkly but still holding their shape.", "name": "Roast tomatoes and toast farro - Toss tomatoes on a tray with the olive oil, salt and pepper. Spread farro on a separate tray. Put both in the oven, farro on the top shelf, tomatoes underneath. Bake for 8 minutes, shaking the trays halfway. The farro should be browned with a nutty flavour, the tomatoes should be a bit wrinkly but still holding their shape.", "url": "https://www.recipetineats.com/farro-salad-with-sizzled-dressing/#wprm-recipe-118808-step-0-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cool tomatoes on the tray while you prep everything else.", "name": "Cool tomatoes on the tray while you prep everything else.", "url": "https://www.recipetineats.com/farro-salad-with-sizzled-dressing/#wprm-recipe-118808-step-0-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cook farro (Note 1) - Put the toasted farro in a saucepan with the vinegar, water and salt. Bring to a boil over high heat then reduce to medium so it is simmering. Cover with lid then simmer for 40 - 45 minutes or until all/most of the liquid is absorbed and the farro is ready. It should still have a bite to it (not soft like pasta) but not a hard centre. Add more water if needed, and keep cooking - don&#39;t be afraid to cook it softer if you want. Drain off excess liquid, if there is any, then transfer to a large bowl. (Taste: a bit tangy, the &quot;vinegar&quot; component used in salad dressings!)", "name": "Cook farro (Note 1) - Put the toasted farro in a saucepan with the vinegar, water and salt. Bring to a boil over high heat then reduce to medium so it is simmering. Cover with lid then simmer for 40 - 45 minutes or until all/most of the liquid is absorbed and the farro is ready. It should still have a bite to it (not soft like pasta) but not a hard centre. Add more water if needed, and keep cooking - don&#39;t be afraid to cook it softer if you want. Drain off excess liquid, if there is any, then transfer to a large bowl. (Taste: a bit tangy, the &quot;vinegar&quot; component used in salad dressings!)", "url": "https://www.recipetineats.com/farro-salad-with-sizzled-dressing/#wprm-recipe-118808-step-0-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Pile eschallots on top. Add coriander and cumin, cook for 30 seconds until light golden and you can smell it. Add garlic and cook for 30 seconds until light golden.", "name": "Sizzling garlic cumin dressing - Heat oil in a small pan over medium low heat. Add coriander and cumin, cook for 30 seconds until light golden and you can smell it. Add garlic and cook for 30 seconds until light golden.", "url": "https://www.recipetineats.com/farro-salad-with-sizzled-dressing/#wprm-recipe-118808-step-0-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Assembling - Immediately pour hot oil over eschallots so it semi-cooks it. Toss. Add spinach, toss. Add tomatoes, gently stir through (some tomato collapsing is encouraged). Pour 1/3 into a serving bowl, crumble over 1/3 goats cheese. Some notes from my experience:\r\n\r\n1. Don't sub thick buttermilk for milk and vinegar with this particular recipe; I found it made the batter WAAAY too thick and unpourable. If you did this and found it's too thick you can add splashes of milk until it's a consistency you can spread around and no one will be the wiser.\r\n\r\n2. I don't know if my propane stove's on crack or if it's because I made the batter thicker than intended but even medium was too hot and cooking the pancakes through at that temp meant burning the sides. To fix this I turned the heat down to medium low, and cooked past the point where holes form on the surface to the point where in some spots the surface batter gained a glossy, translucent sheen. This'll make them easier to flip if you're making bigger pancakes (like me). And the long-cooked side barely got darker than golden brown!\r\n\r\nCheers everyone and thank you Nagi! This ultra crispy Parmesan Crusted Chicken is 5 ingredient, 10 minute magic that happens to be gluten free. The idea with this recipe is that shredded parmesan melts, tuns golden and adheres to the chicken, forming a crust. Parmesan has such an intense flavour that you don't need any other seasonings in this. It tastes like schnitzel, but the coating flavour is far stronger and crunchier (but no carbs!) but is not as thick as a traditional breadcrumb coating. &nbsp;Serve it with cauliflower mash with browned butter for the ultimate low-carb meal!&nbsp;", "datePublished": "2018-01-17T18:27:23+00:00", "image": ["https://www.recipetineats.com/tachyon/2018/01/Parmesan-Crusted-Chicken_1.jpg", "https://www.recipetineats.com/tachyon/2018/01/Parmesan-Crusted-Chicken_1.jpg?resize=500%2C500", "https://www.recipetineats.com/tachyon/2018/01/Parmesan-Crusted-Chicken_1.jpg?resize=500%2C375", "https://www.recipetineats.com/tachyon/2018/01/Parmesan-Crusted-Chicken_1.jpg?resize=480%2C270"], "recipeYield": ["4"], "prepTime": "PT7M", "cookTime": "PT8M", "totalTime": "PT15M", "recipeIngredient": ["500 g / 1 lb   chicken breast (2 pieces) ( (Note 1))", "1  egg", "1  garlic clove (, minced (optional))", "Salt and pepper", "125 g / 4 oz /  1 1/4 cups  shredded parmesan ((Note 2))", "2 tbsp butter ((or more oil))", "1 tbsp olive oil"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cut each breast in half horizontally to make 4 steaks. Thai curries are famous for the sublime aromatic flavours balancing sweet, tart, savoury and spiciness. Thai Yellow Curry is one such magnificent example, with its rich yellow colour, incredible depth of flavour and a heady combination of both fresh and ground herbs and spices.This is made from scratch with a homemade Yellow Curry Paste. There are quite a few ingredients involved but if you truly want the best, it&#39;s worth it!This is a creation the RecipeTin Team is proud to call our own - we worked damn hard on it! (Then we celebrated by making another 100 as the first meals we donated through RecipeTin Meals \u2764\ufe0f)SPICINESS: Adjust by varying fresh chilli. Use 1 for extremely mild, 2 for quite mild, 4 for spicy (but not blow-your-head off).", "datePublished": "2021-08-23T15:00:00+00:00", "image": ["https://www.recipetineats.com/tachyon/2021/08/Thai-Yellow-Curry_30-SQ.jpg", "https://www.recipetineats.com/tachyon/2021/08/Thai-Yellow-Curry_30-SQ.jpg?resize=500%2C500", "https://www.recipetineats.com/tachyon/2021/08/Thai-Yellow-Curry_30-SQ.jpg?resize=500%2C375", "https://www.recipetineats.com/tachyon/2021/08/Thai-Yellow-Curry_30-SQ.jpg?resize=480%2C270"], "recipeYield": ["4"], "prepTime": "PT30M", "cookTime": "PT30M", "totalTime": "PT60M", "recipeIngredient": ["10  dried red chillis ((~6cm/2.5&quot; long), chopped into 1cm / 0.5&quot; pieces (Note 1))", "1 - 4  fresh birds eye chillis (, deseeded, roughly (1 for extremely mild, 4 for fairly spicy, Note 2))", "2  lemongrass stems ((Note 3))", "1 large or 2 small  eschalots (, roughly chopped (~ 1/2 cup) (Note 4))", "2 tbsp fresh turmeric (, finely grated (about 2cm / 0.8&quot; piece) (Note 5))", "2 tbsp galangal (, finely grated (about 2cm / 0.8&quot; piece) (Note 6))", "8 cloves garlic (, roughly chopped)", "1 1/2 tbsp Thai shrimp paste in bean oil ((Note 7))", "1 tsp ground coriander", "1 tsp ground cumin", "1/4 tsp ground cardamom", "1/2 tsp fenugreek powder ((Note 8))", "1/8 tsp white pepper ((sub black))", "3 tbsp vegetable oil ((or canola or peanut oil))", "1  medium potato (, peeled, cut into 2.5cm / 1\" pieces x 1cm/ 0.4\" thick (Note 9))", "1  small carrot (, peeled, sliced into 5mm / 0.2\" slices on the diagonal)", "1 cup chicken stock (, low sodium)", "300 ml / 10oz   coconut cream ((Note 10))", "4 tsp fish sauce (, plus more to taste (Note 11))", "5 tsp white sugar", "2 tsp tamarind puree ((Note 12))", "350g / 12oz  prawns/shrimp (, medium, peeled, tail on optional (700g/1.4lb unpeeled) (Note 13))", "1/2 cup bamboo shoots (, canned, drained, loosely packed (Note 14))", "16  Thai basil leaves ((highly recommended, Note 15))", "1  Red chilli (, finely sliced (optional, use large for not spicy))", "2 tbsp Crispy fried shallots ((optional, store bought, Note 16))", "Jasmine rice"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToSection", "name": "Curry Paste:", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Soak dried chillis: Roughly chop chillies and transfer to bowl, leaving behind seeds. Cover with boiling water and soak for 30 minutes then drain (reserve soaking water).", "name": "Soak dried chillis: Roughly chop chillies and transfer to bowl, leaving behind seeds. Cover with boiling water and soak for 30 minutes then drain (reserve soaking water).", "url": "https://www.recipetineats.com/thai-yellow-curry/#wprm-recipe-67311-step-0-0"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Check spiciness: Have a nibble of soaked chilli, should not be that spicy. If it is spicy, only use 1/3 to 1/2 of the amount (Note 1).", "name": "Check spiciness: Have a nibble of soaked chilli, should not be that spicy. If it is spicy, only use 1/3 to 1/2 of the amount (Note 1).", "url": "https://www.recipetineats.com/thai-yellow-curry/#wprm-recipe-67311-step-0-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Prepare lemongrass: Remove woody top half and outer layers of lemongrass. Grate with microplane. (See in post or video for preparation demo)", "name": "Prepare lemongrass: Remove woody top half and outer layers of lemongrass. Grate with microplane. The trick to cooking duck breast is to start the skin in a cold pan with no oil, then cook it on low heat to let the fat render (melt) which allows the skin to go crispy. Then finish it off in the oven - best way to ensure the flesh is perfectly cooked from edge to edge, for tender, rich, perfect duck slices!As for doneness inside - treat duck like steak rather than chicken breast: it is more tender and juicy if it is medium rare rather than well done (whereas chicken is chewy if still pink!). Though I personally think duck is still enjoyable if well done (eg Chinese BBQ duck is well done and it&#39;s not dry!).You can use this recipe for as many duck breasts as can fit in a pan without crowding it.", "datePublished": "2025-01-31T15:28:05+00:00", "image": ["https://www.recipetineats.com/tachyon/2025/01/Crispy-skin-duck-breast_4.jpg", "https://www.recipetineats.com/tachyon/2025/01/Crispy-skin-duck-breast_4.jpg?resize=500%2C500", "https://www.recipetineats.com/tachyon/2025/01/Crispy-skin-duck-breast_4.jpg?resize=500%2C375", "https://www.recipetineats.com/tachyon/2025/01/Crispy-skin-duck-breast_4.jpg?resize=480%2C270"], "recipeYield": ["1", "1 duck breast"], "prepTime": "PT2M", "cookTime": "PT20M", "recipeIngredient": ["1  duck breast (, boneless, skin on (Note 1))", "1/8 tsp cooking salt / kosher salt", "Pinch  white pepper ((sub finely ground black pepper))"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat the oven to 180\u00b0C/350\u00b0F (160\u00b0C fan-forced).", "name": "Preheat the oven to 180\u00b0C/350\u00b0F (160\u00b0C fan-forced).", "url": "https://www.recipetineats.com/how-to-cook-duck-breast/#wprm-recipe-168675-step-0-0"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Score - Sprinkle half the salt and pepper on the flesh of the duck. I read in the reviews about the filling coming away from the wrapper (which has happened to my dumplings before) so I researched it on other sites. I added 2tsp corn flour and 1 egg and they were perfect, no shrinkage. \r\nAlso steam them gently! \r\nI made some of the mixture into potstickers which I cooked at the same time. ABSOLUTELY!", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Lisa"}, "datePublished": "2025-06-25"}, {"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "reviewBody": "I made this recipe on the Easter weekend and it was great. The pan juices were so good by themselves, I scarcely needed gravy.\r\n\r\nSome changes I made:\r\n1. I skipped the potatoes because we had mash potatoes already.\r\n2. I know you recommended against lamb leg, but leg was $11/kg vs $21/kg for shoulder. So I bought the leg and butterflied it myself. To stop it drying out, I cooked it uncovered for 30 mins, then lowered the temp and covered it for 2 hours about 1/2 cup water in the roasting pan. It came out perfect!\r\n3. Rather, sour cream would have been better like on chili con carne ect. I will give the sour cream a go tomorrow. All in all, I need to make a few little tweaks next time and this will be part of my regular meal rotation. I had a 2 kg chuck cut that was roughly box shaped, so no need for tying with string. I used my enameled dutch oven, and misjudged the capacity. So I ended up roasting all of the potatoes and most of the carrots separately (@ 400 F for about 45 minutes with evoo, salt, pepper, smoked paprika, and Italian herb seasoning). The dutch oven was in the oven at about 300 - 325 for three hours, and then another 3 hrs as low as I could turn down the oven (around 200 F) because we had to go somewhere. The roast was super tender and delicious. I'm sort of glad I did the carrots and (most) of the carrots separately, as it brings out their natural sweetness. A real crowd pleaser, and my new go to recipe for roast beef. Called Confit de Canard in French, duck legs are slow-cooked in duck fat until the meat is meltingly tender, then the skin crisped to golden perfection. This Duck Confit recipe is low-effort and DOESN&#39;T require buckets of duck fat! Simple, yet a lusciously indulgent dish worthy of gracing restaurant tables. It pairs especially well with seafoods, such as the Tuna Steak I shared today.Sauce Vierge was popularised by Michel Gu\u00e9rard, a French chef who championed nouvelle cuisine (literally, &quot;new cuisine&quot;) in the 1970&#039;s, a food style which emphasised freshness, simplicity, and lightness. Really, this sauce couldn&#039;t be a better expression of this style of French cooking!Serve with white meats (chicken, pork), vegetables, use as a salsa-type dip (corn chips, mini crostini), pile onto toasted bread to make bruschetta or crostini, pile over an omelette or frittata, or corn fritters! Malfatti means \u201cbadly formed\u201d in Italian. These irregular spinach ricotta gnocchi-like dumplings may look a bit wonky, but they taste incredible!Like gnudi except with the addition of spinach, this traditional Italian dish can be served straight after boiling them. But it&#039;s really worth a quick 15 minute bake to get a light golden crust on the Malfatti as well as caramelisation on the edges of the Napoli sauce. This is a meal-worthy salad designed to be eaten with a spoon: finely chopped broccoli tossed with slippery pearl couscous, plumped dried cranberries and a nutty salami fry up with red onion and garlic. The red wine vinaigrette is zesty but not too sour thanks to a smidge of honey, and finishing with parmesan is optional, but not really. :)It&#39;s a riot of textures, flavours and colours, and just a great way to use broccoli in a different way. Serve this for lunch with friends, dinner on balmy evenings, or a lazy Sunday lunch with a glass of your favourite white.", "datePublished": "2025-08-20T16:00:00+00:00", "image": ["https://www.recipetineats.com/tachyon/2025/08/Broccoli-pearl-crunch-salad_4.jpg", "https://www.recipetineats.com/tachyon/2025/08/Broccoli-pearl-crunch-salad_4.jpg?resize=500%2C500", "https://www.recipetineats.com/tachyon/2025/08/Broccoli-pearl-crunch-salad_4.jpg?resize=500%2C375", "https://www.recipetineats.com/tachyon/2025/08/Broccoli-pearl-crunch-salad_4.jpg?resize=480%2C270"], "recipeYield": ["4"], "prepTime": "PT25M", "cookTime": "PT15M", "totalTime": "PT70M", "recipeIngredient": ["1 1/2 medium heads broccoli ((4 cups chopped small, spoon-eating size)(Note 1))", "1 tbsp red wine vinegar ((Note 2))", "1/4 tsp cooking salt / kosher salt", "1 cup pearl couscous ((Note 3))", "1/2 cup dried cranberries", "1 tsp olive oil", "100g/ 3 oz  salami (, chopped into 1x1.25cm pieces (0.2 x 1/2&quot;), or bacon (Note 4))", "1/3 cup almonds (, unsalted, natural (or roasted), chopped into big pieces (Note 5))", "1  red onion (, halved, finely sliced)", "2  garlic cloves (, finely minced)", "2 tbsp red wine vinegar ((Note 2))", "1 tbsp honey ((sub maple, or 2 tsp sugar))", "3 tbsp extra virgin olive oil", "1 tsp dijon mustard", "1  garlic clove (, finely minced)", "1 tsp lemon zest (, optional)", "1/4 tsp cooking salt / kosher salt", "1/8 tsp black pepper", "1/4 cup+ parmesan (, finely grated (crumbled feta also lovely))"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Dressing - Shake ingredients in a jar.", "name": "Dressing - Shake ingredients in a jar.", "url": "https://www.recipetineats.com/broccoli-pearl-crunch-salad/#wprm-recipe-183310-step-0-0"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Chop broccoli into small pieces - think, spoon scoop-able size. It only took us 3 years to crack the ultimate, truly crispy Salt and Pepper Squid! Hand on heart, this is crispier than any squid I&#39;ve had in a restaurant, ever. The fry batter is light, super crunchy and not greasy at all. In fact, it&#39;s so crispy it stays crispy even when it&#39;s stone cold!After eliminating rice flour, potato flour and tapioca, we found the perfect ratio of flour to cornflour (cornstarch) that fries up crunchy in mere minutes, before the squid can overcook. But the final key was refrigerating the batter for 30 minutes. This allowed the gluten to develop so the batter clings to the slippery squid better and doesn&#39;t fry up chewy or greasy.", "datePublished": "2024-02-16T16:46:13+00:00", "image": ["https://www.recipetineats.com/tachyon/2024/02/Salt-and-pepper-squid-in-a-bowl.jpg", "https://www.recipetineats.com/tachyon/2024/02/Salt-and-pepper-squid-in-a-bowl.jpg?resize=500%2C500", "https://www.recipetineats.com/tachyon/2024/02/Salt-and-pepper-squid-in-a-bowl.jpg?resize=500%2C375", "https://www.recipetineats.com/tachyon/2024/02/Salt-and-pepper-squid-in-a-bowl.jpg?resize=480%2C270"], "recipeYield": ["3", "3 - 8 people"], "prepTime": "PT15M", "recipeIngredient": ["700 g / 1.4 lb  medium whole baby squid", "500 g / 1 lb  squid tubes (,  already cleaned)", "2/3 cup cornflour / cornstarch", "1/3 cup plain / all-purpose flour", "1/2 tsp baking powder", "1/2 tsp cooking / kosher salt", "1/4 tsp white pepper powder", "2/3 cup cold tap water", "3 \u2013 4 cups vegetable or canola oil ((~4cm / 1.5\" depth in a pot))", "Cooking / kosher salt ( - just a pinch!)", "White pepper powder", "1/2 cup whole egg mayonnaise ( or kewpie)", "1/2 tsp finely grated garlic"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToSection", "name": "Preparing squid:", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cut one side of the squid tube to lay it out in one flat piece. Key step (especially for simple pastas like these) - tossing the sauce with the cooked pasta and a splash of pasta cooking water. The fat in the sauce reacts with the starch in the cooking water, thickening the sauce and making it stick to the pasta strands. This is a wildly popular raw Broccoli Salad by Melissa Clark of the New York Times. The red wine vinegar lightly &quot;cooks&quot; the broccoli so it&#039;s not as hard as plain raw broccoli, then it&#039;s marinated in an intensely flavoured cumin, garlic and sesame infused olive oil. It is unexpectedly good, it&#039;s unique, and I keep making it so I wanted to share the recipe.Not a fan of raw broccoli? This probably isn&#039;t the dish to convert you, I&#039;ll admit. The use of ghee (clarified butter) is an excellent nuance, but I must return a warning.  Vedic Indians would certainly claim to have invented this marvelous product and they have used it for thousands of years.  It carries vital dietary, medicinal, and even spiritual significance for their tradition.  Modern Vaidyas -- master doctors of Ayurveda, who are usually very well versed in what we call \"organic chemistry\" -- will express something near to horror at the suggestion of making ghee in a microwave device.  The E-M radiation generated can disrupt and damage organic bonds in lipids and proteins in unpredictable ways.  You are much better advised to use fire or a simple conductive heat source tp cook the water and milk protein out of butter.  It's easy enough.  And for heaven's sake do not dispose of those coagulated and caramelized solids.  They will add delicious complexity to soups, stews, gravy, and can blend directly with various sugars to make candy.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Scott Hartly"}, "datePublished": "2024-05-07"}, {"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "reviewBody": "Absolutely divine. I generally cook it down in a big pot on the BBQ to keep the vinegar fumes out of the house. After you\u2019ve reduced your bulk quantity just save 1-3 TBSP (depending on the quantity of bearnaise sauce you usually make) in snack-size ziploc bags and pop them all in a container in the freezer. Then you only need to grab eggs and butter (plus more tarragon from the garden if desired) to finish making a batch when steak is on the menu! Super convenient at the end of winter when tarragon dies right off in the garden. This Malaysian Chicken Satay Curry features chicken marinated in a homemade satay seasoning, simmered in a heady peanut satay sauce that&#039;s coconuty and heavily seasoned. Truly restaurant quality. Yet -simple. No hunting down unsual ingredients!Spice level: Pretty warm buzz but not that spicy. 6  birds eye chillies or other small hot red chillies (, finely chopped (Note 3))", "1/4 cup onion ((brown, white or yellow), finely diced (~ 1/4 onion))", "4  garlic cloves (, minced)", "1 cup chicken broth / stock", "3/4 cup peanuts, roasted unsalted, (, chopped, separated)", "2 tsp kecap manis ((Note 4))", "3 tsp dark soy sauce ((Note 5))", "400g / 14oz  coconut milk ((preferably full fat but light will be ok))", "2 tbsp peanut butter (, pure best but spread ok too, crunchy or smooth)", "2 tbsp lime juice (, to taste)", "3  makrut lime leaves ((formerly kaffir lime leaves) (Note 6))", "1  lemongrass stalk (, white part only, smashed to burst open (Note 7))", "Peanuts (, chopped)", "Cilantro / coriander leaves", "Fresh chilli, finely chopped"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Combine Satay Seasoning ingredients in a small bowl.", "name": "Combine Satay Seasoning ingredients in a small bowl.", "url": "https://www.recipetineats.com/chicken-satay-curry/#wprm-recipe-21503-step-0-0"}, {"@type": "HowToSection", "name": "Marinate &amp; Cook Chicken:", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Marinate - DELICIOUS!!!\r\n\r\nI thought I might give a rundown on the success I had with this recipe in an electric pressure cooker using gravy beef. \r\n\r\nI used 500gr beef and more or less followed the same directions as the chicken (didn't need to add the extra water as per Nagi's slow cook directions as pressure cooker uses less water). \r\n\r\nUsed Sautee feature on electric pressure cooker to brown meat first.\r\n\r\nOnce all ingredients had been dumped in, I pressure cooked on high for 25 minutes. Meat was soft and it was late so I left it at that, but I think it could've gone a bit softer, so 30 minutes is probably ideal.\r\n\r\nIMPROVISATIONS/ADDITIONS \r\n\r\n1. Added two diced potatoes so the curry. As a result it came out a bit thicker than I would've liked, but I just added some water at the end to compensate. \r\n\r\n2. Didn't have whole peanuts so used approximately half a cup of crunchy peanut butter that I had on hand. No need to blitz, I just added it in with the stock and coconut milk. The heat from the pre-sauteed beef melted it all in together.  \r\n\r\n3. No fresh garlic so used 2 tsps garlic powder.\r\n\r\n4. Added a head of broccoli florets and baby spinach at the end once pressure cooking was done. Used sautee function until done to my liking (2 minutes for crispy broccoli). \r\n\r\nThis recipe is absolutely delicious, quick and easy. This is a dressing that uses avocado to make it creamy, rather than mayonnaise or loads of oil. It doesn&#039;t taste very avocado-ey because avocados are dense so it needs to be thinned out to make it pourable as a dressing. Rather, think of the avocado as the better-for-you means to get a creamy dressing fix!Excellent use for avocados that are a bit overripe or with brown spotty bits.
